comments:
This course introduces common kinematic, dynamic, and computational
principles and practical examples that are representative of today’s robotic systems. The
three main topics are coordinate system transformations and kinematics, control of
mobile robots, and motion planning of robotic systems. The laboratory component
includes simulation exercises, programming, and numerical modeling using effective
algorithms with applications to problems in engineering, science, and mathematics.
Other topics include interpolation and curve fitting, numerical integration, introduction to
the solution of ordinary and partial differential equations by finite difference, and finite
element methods.
The majority of the students felt that this course was overall difficult, abstract,
and “involved a lot of math” but that eventually they learnt a lot. Yet some noted that the
topics were interesting and the course was helpful for students majoring in MEAM. One
student thought that the lack of a proper textbook and relevant tutors was a noticeable
problem.
Professor Hu was described as “excellent in accessibility and willingness to
discuss with students when they encounter problems.” His notes were regarded as “very
useful.” Students praised that Professor Hu “incorporated several real-world example
problems” in class but hoped that he could give clearer presentations.
Students should be prepared to put in a good deal of work for this course. This
course serves as an elective for MEAM majors.
